[TB_001] The turban, as you can see, is a traditional head covering worn in many cultures. It's fascinating to note that this artwork connects to another exhibit here – the Cavalier hat. Both are historical fashion accessories, albeit from different regions and periods.

[KC_005] The African King Caspar, painted by Gerrit Dou in 1635, is a remarkable oil on panel piece where you see King Caspar wearing an elaborate turban. His attire is adorned with precious stones, much like the turban in our current exhibit.

Visiting both exhibits gives you a unique opportunity to appreciate the artistry and cultural significance of these historical head coverings from different parts of the world. As you move on to see the Cavalier hat, keep an eye out for similarities in design and decoration that connect these artworks across time and continents.

[KC_001] Did you know that King Caspar, as depicted in this artwork, is one of the Three Wise Men from the biblical story? He's often portrayed as a king because traditionally, he brought gold as a gift to the newborn Jesus. It's like if I were visiting a friend and brought them an expensive piece of jewelry instead of flowers or chocolates! Just as this painting captures the essence of King Caspar, your gifts to friends reflect who you are, too.

I'm glad you're interested in learning more about King Caspar, one of the Three Wise Men from the biblical story. [KC_001] He is traditionally depicted as the king who brought gold as a gift to baby Jesus.

Imagine attending a birthday party for a dear friend and wanting to give them something special. That's essentially what King Caspar did in the biblical story, making his role both significant and meaningful within the narrative.
